I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
package of up to $100,000,000 equivalent in yuan, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $40,000,000 
equivalent in yuan; and (ii) a complementary loan of up to $60,000,000 equivalent in yuan to New 
Hope Liuhe Co., Ltd. (NHL) for the Integrated and Sustainable Livestock Value Chain Project in 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project will support the expansion of NHL’s integrated livestock business with the 
construction of two hog farms and a meat-processing plant. Through this project, the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will promote a business model for livestock production that is inclusive; 
resource-efficient; and with less impact on the environment, climate change, and public health.   
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
1.  Project Identification 
 
3.  Importance of livestock in the People’s Republic of China. Livestock contributes to 
nearly half of total gross domestic product generated by the agriculture in the PRC.1 Pork is 
traditionally the most important source of animal protein for PRC consumers and total pork 
consumption was about 55 million tons in 2018, corresponding to half of global pork consumption. 
However, the PRC hog sector is facing severe interrelated issues: biosecurity risks, pollution, 
impact on climate change, antibiotic overuse, and low productivity.  
   
4.  Biosecurity risks. Hog farms in the PRC have historically been exposed to a range of 
animal diseases, which have caused moderate losses. African Swine Fever (ASF), however, is a 
particularly big threat as it is lethal for hogs, highly contagious, and incurable. The first reported 
ASF case in the PRC occurred in August 2018 and the virus has spread to almost every province. 
ASF will reduce the total number of live hogs in the PRC by as much as 50% by the end of 2019. 
Small hog farmers with inadequate biosecurity management systems are expected to bear most 
of the economic losses. To tackle this pressing challenge, the Government of the PRC intensified 
efforts to develop a vaccine (which would be the world’s first), restricted cross-province transport 
of live hogs, and introduced policies to compensate farms that cull infected hogs (footnote 1).    
 
5.  Pollution concerns. The PRC hog sector generates about 864 million tons of animal 
waste per year, equivalent to one-third of total animal waste generated by the PRC livestock 
sector.2 The government has significantly tightened environmental regulations since 2010 to force 
the hog sector to invest more in waste management treatment.  However, enforcing these 
regulations remains a challenge because small hog farms (with fewer than 500 hogs), which 
contribute to about half of total hog production in the PRC, are so numerous and unsophisticated.3 
  
6.  Climate change impact. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations 
reports that livestock contribute to 14.5% of all human-induced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, 
 
1  Sector Overview (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
2  Guangdong Agricultural Science Journal. 2015. PRC academic document code: 1004-874X (2015) 16-0175-05   
3  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Agriculture (press conference, 29 September 2017).

2   
 
of which about 81% is attributable to ruminants and only 9% to hogs,4 largely because the GHG 
emission per unit of pork is much lower than that of beef. Hog farming is more efficient in 
producing animal protein than cattle farming because hog farming requires less feed and water 
per kilogram of animal protein produced, which helps strengthen food security. By encouraging 
the development of large-scale industrial hog farming, the government seeks to mitigate climate 
change through greater efficiency in production and waste management, and to adapt to climate 
change through large farms’ ability to maintain stable and climate-resilient production.   
 
7.  Antibiotic  overuse.  Antibiotics  are  an  acceptable  veterinary  tool  in treating  animal 
diseases when used appropriately. However, antibiotic overuse has become an issue among 
small hog farmers in the PRC, who typically give the hogs feedstuff mixed with antibiotic additives, 
which results in animal wastes contaminated with antibiotic remnants. Animal waste with too much 
antibiotic content cannot be readily used in producing organic fertilizer. Such waste must be 
properly treated, which can be costly.5 If the waste is not properly treated before being discharged 
into the natural environment, the antibiotic remnants can contaminate underground water and 
contribute to growing antimicrobial resistance, posing a significant threat to public health.   
 
8.  Modernization  to  increase  resource  efficiency.  The  government  promotes  the 
modernization of hog farming not only to tackle environmental and health concerns but also to 
increase farming efficiency. As the number of hogs per sow per year increased from 14 to 18 from 
2010 to 2018 in the PRC, the number of sows decreased from 50 million to 30 million. This trend 
will continue as the percentage of modern farms increases and the number of hogs per sow per 
year is still lower than in Europe and North America, where it is about 27-30. Since total pork 
demand in the PRC started to decrease slightly in 2014 and is expected to continue to decrease 
slowly until 2028 (as the middle-class grows and continues to diversify its diet), there is no 
pressing need to produce more pork. There is, however, an urgent need to produce better pork 
(as demand for high-quality and traceable pork rises), with much fewer resources; reduced animal 
losses due to diseases; and less impact on the environment, climate, and public health.  
 
9.  Project selection. The project team identified NHL as a suitable candidate for ADB’s 
support because: (i) as an agribusiness conglomerate that operates along the entire livestock 
value chain (i.e. animal feed production, livestock farming, slaughtering, and meat processing), 
NHL is committed to high standards of environmental protection, climate change mitigation, 
animal health, and food safety; (ii) NHL has a good track record of building and operating 
integrated hog farms with advanced modern technology to maximize farming efficiency and 
productivity; and (iii) NHL is willing to partner with ADB to improve its environmental and social 
standards of its hog farming operations, following ADB’s policies and requirements.  
 
2.  Project Design 
 
10.  The project includes the construction of: (i) a hog farm in Huanghua, Hebei Province, with 
a production capacity of 280,000 hogs per year (Huanghua farm); (ii) a hog farm in Xiangzhou, 
Guangxi Province, with a production capacity of 360,000 hogs per year (Xiangzhou farm); and 
(iii) a meat processing facility in Pinggu district, Beijing, with a processing capacity of 3,000 tons 
of pork meat per year (meat-processing plant). The farms will outsource about 50% of the hog-
fattening process to about 1,000 small hog farmers within a radius of 100 kilometers of each farm. 
 
4  P.J. Gerber, H. Steinfeld, B. Henderson, A. Mottet, C. Opio, J. Dijkman, A. Falcucci, and G. Tempio. 2013. Tackling 
Climate Change Through Livestock: A Global Assessment of Emissions and Mitigation Opportunities. Rome Food 
and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. http://www.fao.org/3/a-i3437e.pdf 
5  Government of the PRC, Ministry of Agriculture, Breeder Hog Testing Center. 2016. 
   http://cj.zhue.com.cn/a/201609/19-268688.html (in Chinese).

3 
 
11.  Integrated and inclusive hog farming model. NHL started as an animal feed producer 
and gradually expanded to poultry and hog farming and meat production as part of its integrated 
value chain strategy. In 2018, NHL produced 2.5 million hogs and 278,000 tons of pork meat. 
NHL adopts a contract hog farming model where NHL supplies weaned piglets and other farming 
inputs (such as feed, medicine, and vaccines) to contract farmers and buys back the hogs at a 
guaranteed minimum fee. The cost of the piglets and farming inputs is deducted from the fee. The 
fee is adjusted based on a set of metrics (such as the feed conversion ratio and the hog mortality 
rate) to incentivize good performance. The fee is also adjusted based on market prices, but not 
lower than the guaranteed minimum. The contract farming model helps farmers mitigate market 
risk and earn a stable income. NHL provides extension services and financing support for farm 
construction and operations to ensure waste management and biosecurity standards and achieve 
an optimal scale of operations.    
  
12.  Strong biosecurity management. NHL is well-positioned to ensure a high biosecurity 
standard because of the integrated nature of its business model. NHL implements biosecurity 
management best practices on all its hog farms, such as (i) designing multiple access zones with 
different quarantine requirements for input suppliers, farm managers, and farm employees; (ii) 
supplying feed to hog farms from nearby NHL feed mills and selling finisher hogs to NHL slaughter 
houses; and (iii) using NHL trucks to transport feed to NHL hog farms, and hogs to NHL slaughter 
houses. For its contract farms, where biosecurity is inherently weaker, NHL has designed a 
standard operating procedure for its employees to regularly inspect the farms with the aid of smart 
thermometers, which measure the body temperature of live hogs for potential ASF symptoms. 
NHL has also installed surveillance cameras at the contract farms. 
 
13.  Efficient animal waste treatment. NHL employs a waterless technique to collect animal 
waste. A mechanical scraper system is installed underneath hog barns and separates solid and 
liquid waste. Solid manure is being transferred to storage and turned into organic fertilizer, while 
wastewater is treated in a biogas digester to produce methane gas for heating during winter and 
canteen cooking on the farms, thereby mitigating climate change. The treated water and fertilizer 
can be used in nearby crop fields as part of the company’s sustainable circular agricultural system. 
 
14.  Climate change mitigation. NHL will become more efficient because of its integrated 
supply chain. Mortality will be lower by better biosecurity management and by higher sow fertility 
resulting from the import of productive swine genetics. Less animal waste will be discharged and 
fewer inputs consumed, and greater efficiency will shrink NHL’s carbon footprint. NHL will 
incorporate a biodigester system into its hog farming waste management strategy, which will 
further reduce GHG emissions in two ways. First, the biodigester will convert animal waste into 
biogas and captures methane which would otherwise be released into the atmosphere. Second, 
the biogas generated will be used in farms to replace electricity or other fuels to heat the facilities.  
 
15.  Antibiotic-free pork processing. In 2017, NHL signed a partnership agreement with 
Cooperl Arc Atlantique (Cooperl), a cooperative of French farmers and one of the largest hog 
producers in Europe, to establish a 50:50 joint-venture to produce antibiotic-free pork products in 
the PRC. Housed in NHL’s existing food-processing factories, the proposed meat-processing 
plant is NHL’s first processing plant that will pilot production of antibiotic-free meat. The joint-
venture will initially import frozen antibiotic-free meat from France, until such time as NHL is able

4   
 
to supply antibiotic-free meat from its nearby farm in Zhangjiakou, Hebei Province, which is now 
under construction and will be operated according to Cooperl’s antibiotic-free standards.6      
 
3.  The Borrower 
 
16  Founded in 1982 by Liu Yonghao, NHL is a leading integrated animal protein producer in 
the PRC, with major operations in animal feed production, livestock farming (poultry and hog), 
slaughtering, and meat processing. NHL is the largest animal feed producer in the PRC with an 
annual production capacity of about 16 million tons and a market share of about 8%. It is the 
second largest poultry breeder and the largest white-feather chicken farming company in the 
PRC, with annual sales volume of about 800 million chickens. In 2013, NHL started hog farming, 
which has since become the company’s the most profitable business. NHL is listed on the 
Shenzhen Stock Exchange and had a market capitalization of about $13.5 billion as of November 
2019. The company has more than 500 subsidiaries, with 61,000 employees, and established 
operations in more than 20 countries across Asia, North America, Europe, and Africa. Liu 
Yonghao remains the company’s controlling shareholder, with about 29% ownership directly and 
indirectly. In 2013, Liu Yonghao stepped down as chair of NHL. His daughter, Liu Chang, replaced 
him and is fully responsible for NHL’s management and operations. 
 
17  Integrity due diligence was conducted in accordance with ADB’s Integrity Due Diligence 
Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations.7 No significant or potentially significant integrity risks 
were identified. No tax integrity due diligence was required.8 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
18  Impacts. The project is aligned with the key objectives of the PRC’s Thirteenth Five-Year 
Plan (2016 - 2020): (i) development of agricultural production and value chains, and (ii) integration 
of rural areas into regional industry chains and production networks.9    
 
19  Outcome. The project’s outcome is the scale-up of efficient, inclusive, and sustainable 
agribusiness. The project will (i) improve the resource efficiency of hog farming in the PRC by 
increasing the number of hogs per sow, improving the feed conversion ratio, and reducing water 
usage; (ii) promote an inclusive business model through an increase in the income of farm workers 
and contract farmers; and (iii) mitigate climate change by adopting waste management systems 
such as the biogas digester facility. The project will avoid at least 8,000 tons10 of carbon dioxide 
equivalents per annum starting in 2022. 
 
20  Outputs. The outputs of the project will be: (i) construction of a meat-processing plant 
with antibiotic-free processing line; (ii) construction of two hog farms with waste management 
facilities; (iii) generation of local jobs; (iv) support to the local economy; and (v) creation of a safe 
and productive environment for both women and men workers.    
 
 
6  Antibiotic-free farming is a new concept in the PRC and the market for premium antibiotic-free meat needs to be 
tested. The Zhangjiakou farm will provide enough hogs for the antibiotic-free processing line in the proposed meat-
processing plant. The Huanghua and Xiangzhou farms, which are located farther away, will not be antiotic-free but 
will adopt best veterinarian practices ensuring an appropriate use of antibiotics as treatment for bacterial infections.

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
 
21  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is aligned with 
Strategy 2030 which calls for ADB “to scale up its financing for agribusiness” and “to promote 
gender equality in at least 75% of the number of ADB’s committed operations by 2030”.11 The 
project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the PRC, which 
supports (i) promoting rural development and food security by improving market connectivity and 
agricultural value chain linkages; (ii) increasing agricultural productivity; (iii) improving food safety; 
and (iv) promoting innovative technology.12 
 
22  Consistency with sector strategy and ADB operations. The project is consistent with 
the Strategy 2030’s Operational Plan for Priority 5 (Promoting Rural Development and Food 
Security, 2019–2024), which calls for (i) “modern, sustainable, and responsible corporate farming 
models”;  (ii)  the  “integration  of  farmers,  agribusinesses,  and  consumers  into  efficient  and 
sustainable value chains”; (iii) the reduction in “agriculture's contribution to GHG emissions 
through improved farming and livestock practices”; and (iv) “food safety and traceability systems 
development”.13 The project will complement a PRC sovereign project, the Yangtze River Green 
Ecological Corridor Comprehensive Agriculture Development Project, which aims to develop an 
integrated management approach and emphasize green development, environmental protection, 
and rehabilitation.14 Potential collaboration includes supporting hog contract farmers within the 
Yangtze River Basin to upgrade the waste management facilities. The collaboration will help small 
hog farmers comply with environmental regulations and improve the environmental and ecological 
sustainability of the Yangtze River Economic Belt.

G.  Unique Features 
 
24  The  project  is  ADB’s  first  assistance  to  an  integrated  agribusiness  conglomerate 
pioneering an antibiotic-free concept in the livestock sector. The project has a unique combination 
of development themes: inclusive business,16 sustainable environmental management, climate 
change mitigation, and gender mainstreaming.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance  
 
25  ADB will provide NHL with a long-term corporate loan package of up to $100,000,000 
equivalent in yuan, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $40,000,000 equivalent in yuan, and (ii) a 
complementary loan of up to $60,000,000 equivalent in yuan. A loan has a tenor of 7 years with 
a grace period of 3 years. ADB is exploring the possibility of mobilizing parallel loans from 
domestic commercial banks and international development finance institutions with an amount of 
up to $70,000,000 equivalent in yuan, as a potential substitute to up to $10,000,000 equivalent in 
yuan of the A loan and to all or part of the complementary loan.    
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  ADB assistance will add value on three fronts: 
(i)  Gender mainstreaming. ADB will help NHL implement a gender action plan.   
(ii)  Long-term capital. NHL relies primarily on internally generated cash and short 
and  medium-term  debt  to  finance  its  expansion.  ADB  will  provide  long-term 
financing which is not readily available from commercial banks.  
 
16 About 50% of the proposed hog production from the two farms will be undertaken using the contract-farming model. 
Most of the employees and contract farmers are expected to be the “base of pyramid” population.

7 
 
(iii)  Safeguard  best  practices.  ADB  will  help  NHL  implement  an  improved 
environmental and social management plan following best international safeguard 
practices on biosecurity, waste management, and animal welfare; and monitor the 
company’s progress during project implementation.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
27  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category B), involuntary resettlement (category C) and 
indigenous peoples (category C).  
 
28  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and 
the  institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  NHL  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and 
environmental impacts are deemed adequate. Potential risks and impacts during construction are 
generally site specific, and short term, and can be effectively managed by good engineering, 
construction, and housekeeping practices based on construction environmental management 
plans. No involuntary resettlement or indigenous people issues are envisaged for the project. All 
new projects will either be constructed within existing premises and facilities or on adjoining land 
belonging to industrial parks or zones. The proceeds of ADB’s investment will not support 
subprojects with significant environmental or social impacts.  
 
29  An external third party conducted a corporate audit in accordance with the Safeguard 
Policy Statement. The audit assessed the company’s operations as complying with statutory 
requirements. It deemed the company’s current environmental and social systems, processes, 
and practices commensurate with the risks and impacts associated with the company’s business 
and operations. ADB and NHL agreed to a corrective action plan.  
 
30  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), NHL has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment 
in its operations. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: (i) increase women’s 
inclusion in employment opportunities at the project farms and meat-processing plant; (ii) increase 
procurement of operational goods and services from women-owned businesses; (iii) ensure that 
women and men receive equal pay for equal work at the project farms and plant; (iv) develop and 
implement an anti-sexual harassment policy, including by assigning trained managers to facilitate 
implementation; and (v) provide sex-disaggregated sanitation and change facilities.17 NHL will 
submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB.18 
 
31  NHL will (i) apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list, (ii) ensure that investments 
using ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by national laws and 
regulations, and (iii) establish and maintain an appropriate environmental and social management

B.  Anticorruption Policy  
32.  NHL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.

D.  Assurances 
 
34.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),21 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to NHL. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the Board of Directors.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan complies with the Articles of Agreement of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve (i) an A loan of up to

in yuan to New Hope Liuhe Co., Ltd for the Integrated and Sustainable Livestock Value Chain 
Project in the People’s Republic of China, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The project will support the expansion of New Hope Liuhe Co., Ltd.'s integrated livestock business with the construction of two hog farms and a meat-processing plant. Through this project, the Asian Development Bank will promote a business model for livestock production that is inclusive; resource-efficient; and with less impact on the environment, climate change, and public health.
